review_title: A knife it the back as management philosophy
pros: Good tech stack. Smart coworkers
cons: High pressure environment with heavy politics. It's a knives out type of workplace. Only place I've worked where it's feels like teammates are pitted against each other to create competition. * Watched competent teammates have their good ideas given away to others because they were disliked by leadership, then fired for not producing. * Bonuses and awards determined arbitrarily rather than business impact. * Dirty tricks to insure one's own work is launched over teammates. * Constantly escalating goals that expect a YoY revenue to increase an order of magnitude over your salary. * Management can be hostile and demeaning.

pros: Salary is good, the same as FAANG.
cons: - WLB: The company, despite being valued at around 30 billion, lacks work-life balance and effective management strategies. US employees are required to work overtime frequently to accommodate the Korean business team, which could be prevented with better long-term planning and clear milestones. - Poor management culture: the managers lack a long-term vision and frequently change plans, causing developers to work on weekends, nights, and holidays. Alternative days off promised by managers are not reliable since plans are subject to frequent changes. - Too much politic: The company culture is politically driven, and some employees who talk well but do little work tend to receive better performance reviews due to the stack-ranking system. This job can negatively impact one's mental health, and earning the same amount by working two or more jobs is a more viable option than working here.

pros:
-Resources of a big company.
-If you really want, you can get to know people from other teams.
-People mostly respect what you do on all different levels.
-Somewhere between an American and Korean company.
-Higher ups tend to be foreigners and speak English.

-Due to the covid surge, it's work from home 90% of the time which is difficult to see in Korean society, but a huge plus.
-Invests in translators for every meeting which was different and useful.
cons:
-Sometimes feels like a smaller startup.
-Still quite disorganized and doesn't have a strong system in the main headquarters.
-About 90% of the company still speaks Korean and expects you to also speak it professionally. If you work with english-speakers though, it won't be as big of an issue.

-Things can move incredibly fast if a sudden project is prioritized but it's usually without any warning.

-Interview process took a whole month and was a full 5-step process.

pros: Plenty of interesting work if you don't care about compensation and credit/recognition.
cons:
The harder and smarter you work the less recognition/promotion/compensation you will get. This is because the senior leaders don't want to reward those who deserve as they are worried they might transfer to another org. So they just dangle the carrot just enough for you to stick around till appraisal and then flat out refuse to give you anything, because you can't go to another org now. 

The Indians in the company have managed to make the HRs dummy and hire a lot of Indians post IPO. It is a Korean company run by mediocre Indians. 

These mediocre Indians have formed a cartel. They cover up their incompetency. Promote only Indians. Are highly political and cover for each other.

They also hoard information and only share it with other Indians. They take credit for anything their team does. And compliment each other to the leadership so that the leadership is satisfied with them and approves hiring more Indians. 

All the loyal employees who have been in coupang for many years helping the company go IPO were not rewarded. Random Indian Jokers who know nothing were parachuted above them post IPO. Zero growth. Half the pay as the Indians and no recognition. Sums up why all good resources have left the company. 

Senior leadership is clueless about marketing and tech. So they focus only on ops and sales and only grill the ops and sales teams to deliver. If tech says it needs 3 months to make some feature, they will accept it, even if it really is a 2 day job. And marketing has just always been increasing budget without figuring how to optimize CAC. No strategy and no accountability. 

Any good senior leader/executive hired is quickly fired because of the CFO. Anyone who picks a fight with the CFO for the right reasons, gets cornered by the Indian cartel who convince Bom that the person is useless and needs to leave. Alberto (ex CFO), Dan Rawson (head of 3p marketplace), Thuan (CTO) and many more are victims of one executive's over ambition. Right now it is silly that such a big company is effectively head by one person. The CFO is the COO, CTO, CMO of the company.

pros: Excellent benefits and working environment, some great coworkers (most, not all)
cons:
Management is feeling the pressure from last year's IPO and the freefall in valuation since then. Unfortunately they seem to pass this pressure directly down to engineers, sucking the joy out of working on cool problems and replacing it with pressure to deliver features to the user and revenue improvements to the stockholder. The company cannot retain senior level talent and up, and seems desperate to hire level 5+ to the point of making questionable hiring decisions.

However, the most important downside is that once new engineers are brought on, there is nothing in the way of onboarding to meet coworkers, build rapport, and get new hires up to speed with company systems, practices, and codebase, and there is no communication from management about expectations in your new role. My manager in particular did not seem to know what knowledge is needed for onboarding, details of the codebase, or even important administrative procedures, and makes employees suffer because he does not deliver performance assessments so that they can be acted upon. 

New hires are expected to feel it out in the dark and get themselves running, and fast because the company needs results. This is not helped by the mostly remote work arrangement in which many of the engineers you need to talk to (who you have never met!) are working while you are sleeping and vice versa, nor is it helped by a few (not many, but enough) personalities who would rather feel pride in their status than try to help you out.

Steer clear of this company if you have any other choice.

pros: Being forced to use MSOffice will help you appreciate Google Apps at next job.
cons:
It probably sounds crazy but I think Coupang is the worst tech job in USA in 2021, compared to market performance. I am writing to prevent someone making mistake I made.

- Work/life balance is terrible. If you work at Coupang, you must work Seoul hours. The recruiter or hiring manager might lie to you and say "we are heading in direction of building leadership in the US and being autonomous" but that is a lie. All decisions, strategy, everything happens on Seoul time and you will need to spend your evenings and late nights working. It is exhausting.

- The stock price is 50% down from IPO, it is the biggest loser of the "covid era". I am not aware of any unicorn+ tech which lost more. For reference, WeWork is down 18% in same time. And it's not clear when the bottom comes. There are still some good fundamentals about Coupang's business and there is a positive argument to be made for recovery, but that's a long way And there are tons of insiders waiting to sell out if recovery happens (You can see them all saying this if you check Blind). Even if the stock does recover some day (and I honestly think it will be ok eventually), I don't think you can believe it's better than tech industry average at this point. There's definitely no reason to justify the work/life balance and other issues.

- Many of the pre-IPO fully vested folks just bailed. Entire leadership groups disappeared. There is a leadership crisis happening. Many more pre-IPO folks are resting and vesting and mostly interested in hiding from risky politics. Many ppl's top priority is not drawing attention to themselves.

- All decisions are made by a small group of people in Seoul. They don't say "here is a problem, go understand it and figure out the best solution", instead they say "Do exactly X, because we already decided it's the right solution". You are not involved in deciding X, and btw if X doesn't work that is your fault, not theirs. If they get bored or move on to the next problem, they just stop showing up to meetings or responding to emails. This is not a bottom up Silicon Valley company, it's extremely Top Down, you're just low level pawn.. Most of my time has been working on pointless strategies decided by ppl in Seoul.

I don't feel any upside to my work, and I don't feel I can work on any real problems, just politics. I feel exhausted and humiliated that I destroyed my earning potential during biggest tech market growth ever.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Just want to clarify some disturbing comments from other review. 

-US office does use budget for its' employees like hosting annual company day at resort and providing christmas gifts. Office managers also try to celebrate personal events as well.  

-Though it's a Korean start-up, there are no more than 10 Koreans in the US office and we have interpreters to support every meeting with HQ. 

-The US office might not be diverse enough, however, I don't think it's fair to say some people are not sociable because of their race. Overall, people are nice and we have a collaborative engineering culture. 

-We don't work under restrictive environment. We have a ping-pong table at the center of the office and I'm not sure how someone can think you have to be quiet. Teams are holding stand-ups and discussing issues simultaneously. 

-I haven't seen people quitting recently because we'd have farewell lunch if there are. I heard a case or two where people got fired due to performance issues. 

-US office is still pretty small and you'll have autonomy here.
cons: Management can be better by having more empathy towards employees and having more frequent 1:1s. As said, we're still figuring out and improving on different ways to structure the team.

pros: Remote allows for good work life balance
cons:
High turnover all positions. Sometimes you see people leave each week.
Pay is minimum wage and never more.
There is no room for growth, so I suggest using this position as leverage for another more promising job elsewhere. In the eyes of Coupang, you are expendable. Full-time employees also view you the same and treat you as such. Also seems that FT employees remain in same position forever as well.

review_title: Wish I could give zero stars...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- catered lunches 2x a week
- massage chair in private room
- quiet, safe buildings (neighbors are nice)
- smaller office ( >50 people)
cons:
- management does not communicate or give clarity, gossips with other employees while excluding others
- no big budget for employees' well-being and growth (aka tries to be as cheap as possible, which is unusual for Silicon Valley culture)
- language barrier (you will feel more included if you are a Korean that sucks up to the bosses)
- no diversity (mostly older Chinese/Indian engineers that don't like to socialize)
- restrictive environment-- you will hear "SHHH!!" if you try to talk to your fellow employees so you are not encouraged to make friends. I was told that the Recruiting team had a "bad rep" for talking too loud, even though it's clearly part of their job to talk about potential hires
- MANY people quit or are fired-- there's no advance notice if you are being replaced, you could walk in one day and just be fired (part of the Senior HR Management's lack of honesty and tendency to manipulate the environment). Many others have quit because they cannot handle the toxic environment
- Not enough checks & balances-- there's no manager training or groups of managers working together, so one holds too much reign

review_title: Exciting opportunity but Korean corporate culture lingers in a negative way
pros: A fast growing and exciting company to work for in terms of its current trajectory. There are a lot of great people in this company and a lot of domestic and foreign talent. The company's HQ is in a nice area in Seoul.
cons: Too many negative elements of corporate Korean culture exist. For example, one of the team leaders in the HR division tries to use his position in an inappropriate manner with younger female employees and has a reputation for doing so. However, as is typical in Korean corporates, the lack of transparency in internal policy combined with the Korean "old boys" internal political network leaves little in terms of recourse AND creates an atmosphere of fear of retaliation.

review_title: Awesome company and even better coworkers!
pros:
- Incredible, talented coworkers who actually care about the business and team as a whole

- politics present, but kept to a minimum level.

-flexible working hours and free lunches!
cons:
- Evening meetings with Korea can make WLB tricky for some people

-Improvements can be made about inter-team comms

-Pay is slightly below standard for a tech company in Downtown Seattle, not too serious though since benefits are pretty generous

- Growing pains! our team is still not big enough to cope with insane growth.

-can't get to experience the exciting part in Korea(they don't operate in USA for ecommerce :( )

pros: There are many excellent person. Interview processes are so good and high that non-excellent people can be filtered out in Korea.
cons:
Company is failing in focusing on developing fast and creative services. Managers in middle tier are not good. CEO suggested right vision and led company right direction, but these days he seems he don't care about services, products, people any more.

Company is no longer start-up. It already is large company. Project Owner doesn't create new businesses, they don't focus on developing service but personal connection politically. 

Team organizations are changing like bad large company. A small full stack agile team is changing to a functional large team. Platforms for s/w engineer are horrible. Some platform teams force other teams to use their systems that have very low-quality than aws systems, although company use aws now and there are already similar systems in aws.

pros:
Coupang is rated as one of the “50 Smartest Companies 2016” by MIT, the only South Korean company on the list. It's viewed as the Amazon of Korea, but it's more than just Amazon. Coupang owns its entire end-to-end supply chain, which means that it's able to provide last-mile service to each of the customers in South Korea, whereas Amazon does not. (Also delivery drivers are well treated by Coupang, which is always a bonus knowing your company cares about all the employees.) Then you can imagine all the things that we can design and optimize over to produce the best customer experience. 

Palo Alto and Seattle offices are very much team oriented. Each team primarily consists of product owner, data engineers and data scientists.

# Nice and smart people.

# Lots of interesting problems to work on, and you have the power to initiate projects within the team.

# Manager is very capable and dedicated, making an effort in connecting with each team and providing helpful feedbacks.

# Very flexible working hours. 

# Premium coffees! Twice a week lunch catering, and once a week afternoon happy hours (with beer and fun activities). Tons of fruits and snacks.

# Ping pong table! It is one of the most popular activities among folks in Palo Alto.

# Palo Alto office is located next to Bay trails, making it pleasant to take lunch-time walks/jogs and Pokemon adventures.

Overall, I cannot think of one day that I didn't have fun at the office.
cons:
# Time difference sometimes requires you to work at nights, but the Korean teams are very friendly and helpful. With that said, managing your time well and taking a conscious effort to make sure communications can go as smoothly as possible definitely can help everyone out.

# As a remote office, it can be difficult to experience the excitement going on in South Korea regarding the business growth, but CEO's visits from time to time certainly help.

review_title: Coupang does have huge growth potential
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Wow. I am surprised there are so many negative reviews about Coupang...They really are doing big things. I mean no company is perfect but it meets all the things I care the most.

- #1 e-commerce company in Korea (They are SUPER popular in Korea)
- Huge growth potential (whether company or professional) 
- No hierarchy. It's a pretty flat organization with a decent team size (~40 in Palo Alto)
- Flexible working hours 
- BUNCH of benefits and perks!!
cons: It is a fast paced environment so you need to be flexible when priorities change

review_title: Disappointing due to toxic upper management
job_title: Product Owner in Abu Dhabi, Abu Dhabi
pros: As many other reviews noted, the company has potential and there are great people sprinkled throughout (although they are leaving quickly). There are opportunities to take on responsibility because of some of the chaos. Coupang is probably the best ecommerce app in Korea (Gmarket is the number one site and it is not even close) so there is a lot of pride in maintaining that.
cons:
Upper management is nasty. The CEO has a small circle of trust that blindly try to duplicate what they did at Amazon but they are too arrogant to see that Korea is a different market. 

There is a fake data driven culture: when a subordinate tries to make a case, it is only heard if it aligns with what management wants to hear. Even if it isn't what they want to hear, you quickly see what happens to people who rock the boat: insults, humiliation, and ostracisation 

The fake data driven culture undermines the principles of Agile development and so "value" creation becomes about keeping your boss or your team in upper management's good graces

Good people are leaving, and FAST. The kind of coworkers you don't mind working hard for and late with because you are achieving amazing things are leaving for places where they can grow and be empowered. Many of those that are choosing to stay are political people who try to get in good with the right crowd.

NO stock, and only stock options for senior employees. 

Terrible work life balance

Terrible amenities. There are no sinks. There are disgusting buckets placed next to the water coolers that become full of milk, water, and coffee by noon and stink. Bathrooms are not air conditioned so they just become steam rooms during the summer.

job_title: Product Owner in San Francisco, CA
pros: Some international exposure, but comes at a major cost
cons:
You can find the company's growth rate from publicly available sources.  It's barely growing, and, the growth it does have comes from "buying customers".  The Korean based retail conglomerate, which controls the vast majority of Korean retail market, woke up to the fact that Coupang is stealing their customers.  Since that time, about 2 years ago, said conglomerate retailers has been bleeding Coupang dry.  Given that Coupang is but a drop in the bucket, relative to the said larger company, it's not a hard task for them to do.   It's for this reason that the largest US e-commerce player didn't go into the Korean market.  In other words, your options have a fair chance of being worthless.

Work culture is terrible.   Honestly, you couldn't imagine a worse culture.
